16.139	The component’s work contributed to three countries conducting national mapping exercises on the structure of industry sectors manufacturing and trading chemicals possibly used in illicit drug manufacture, which met the planned target.

16.141	The component’s work contributed to 55 Member States engaging in voluntary cooperation with the private sector to prevent trafficking and marketing of new psychoactive substances and non-medical synthetic opioids through national, regional and global public-private events, which exceeded the planned target of 25 Member States.

children.text: Result 3: strengthened capacity of Member States to ensure adequate availability of internationally controlled substances for medical, scientific and industrial purposes – Proposed programme plan for 2026

16.143	The submission by Member States of accurate and comprehensive estimates and assessments of national requirements for controlled substances for licit purposes and related statistics enables the International Narcotics Control Board to carry out its mandate to promote the implementation of the international drug control treaties and ensure the availability of internationally controlled substances for medical, scientific and industrial purposes. The component, through e-modules and virtual and in-person capacity-building activities delivered through the Board’s learning programme, has strengthened the level of knowledge of Member States of the international control mechanisms to ensure that the use of narcotic drugs, psychotropic substances and precursors is limited to medical, scientific and industrial purposes.
Lessons learned and planned change

16.144	The lesson for the component was that the International Narcotics Control Board learning e-modules are an important tool to improve Member States’ knowledge of the control mechanisms and provide a solid foundation for treaty-based reporting to the Board. In applying the lesson, the component will continue to encourage countries and territories, particularly in Africa, Central Asia and the Caribbean, and the Pacific island States, to utilize the e-modules to close knowledge gaps related to the submission of data.
16.145	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 16.XXXII).

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Technical adjustments
16.150	As reflected in table 16.23 (1), resource changes reflect a net increase of $692,700, which includes the following:

(a)	Policymaking organs. A net decrease of $462,000 comprises the removal of one-time provisions under other staff costs ($83,900), consultants ($49,200), travel of representatives ($207,200), travel of staff ($85,500) and contractual services ($36,200) related to the non-recurrent resource requirements for the preparatory meetings held in 2025 for the Fifteenth United Nations Congress on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice;
(b)	Subprogramme 1, Countering transnational organized crime. A net increase of $1,010,700 comprises:

(i)	The removal of one-time provisions under experts ($24,900), travel of representatives ($33,800) and furniture and equipment ($44,200) related to the non-recurrent resource requirements for 2025 to promote the rapid entry into force of the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/243;

(ii)	Additional requirements of $1,113,600 related to the delayed impact of 15 posts established in 2025 to support the implementation of the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/243, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for new posts;
(c)	Subprogramme 6, Research, trend analysis and forensics. A net increase of $144,000 comprises:

(i)	The removal of one-time provisions under contractual services ($700) related to the non-recurrent resource requirements for 2025 for the promotion of international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development;

(ii)	Additional requirements of $144,700 related to the delayed impact of two temporary posts established in 2025 to support the promotion of international cooperation to combat illicit financial flows and strengthen good practices on assets return to foster sustainable development, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/234, which were subject to a 50 per cent vacancy rate in accordance with the established practice for new posts.
New and expanded mandates
16.151	As reflected in table 16.23 (1), resource changes reflect a net increase of $1,012,800, which includes the following:

(a)	Policymaking organs. A net increase of $627,000 comprises the provision under other staff costs ($124,700), consultants ($101,100), travel of representatives ($341,800), travel of staff ($21,700) and contractual services ($37,700) with respect to new and expanded mandates relating to the Fifteenth United Nations Congress on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice, scheduled to be held in the United Arab Emirates in 2026, pursuant to Economic and Social Council resolution 155 C (VII) and General Assembly resolutions 415 (V), 46/152, 56/119 and 78/223;
(b)	Subprogramme 1, Countering transnational organized crime. A net increase of $385,800 comprises:

(i)	The provision under other staff costs ($1,200), consultants ($86,700), travel of staff ($52,600), contractual services ($132,900) and general operating expenses ($41,600) with respect to new and expanded mandates relating to the United Nations Convention against Cybercrime, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/243;

(ii)	The provision under other staff costs ($70,800) with respect to new mandates relating to strengthening and promoting effective measures and international cooperation on organ donation and transplantation to prevent and combat trafficking in persons for the purpose of organ removal and trafficking in human organs, pursuant to General Assembly resolution 79/189.
Other changes

16.152	As reflected in table 16.23 (1), resource changes reflect an increase of $5,000, resulting from a higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of United Nations Headquarters, and a set of cost-neutral changes, as shown below:
(a)	Subprogramme 1, Countering transnational organized crime. A net decrease of $17,500, which comprises:

(i)	The reduced scope of expertise required in the area of organized crime and illicit trafficking, offset by additional support required for the collection and analysis of the data in preparation for the thirteenth session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime ($9,200);

(ii)	Lower travel requirements related to transnational organized crime processes and ad hoc meetings, offset by additional support required for the collection and analysis of data in preparation for the thirteenth session of the Conference of the Parties to the United Nations Convention against Transnational Organized Crime ($7,500);

(iii)	Reduced communication costs ($800). These reduced requirements under consultants, travel of staff and general operating expenses supported the proposed increase under contractual services under programme support to strengthen the provision to cover the costs of data processing services, including workstation support and licences;

(b)	Subprogramme 6, Research, trend analysis and forensics. Resource changes reflect a decrease of $3,800, which resulted largely from reduced requirements under contractual services and travel of staff for this subprogramme and supported the proposed increase under contractual services for programme support to strengthen the provision to cover the costs of data processing services, including workstation support and licences;

(c)	Subprogramme 9, Provision of secretariat services and substantive support to the United Nations intergovernmental bodies, the International Narcotics Control Board and the United Nations Congress on Crime Prevention and Criminal Justice. Resource changes reflect a decrease of $3,800, which comprises:

(i)	The overall cost-neutral conversion of two general temporary assistance positions of a continuing nature to regular posts, which entails an increase of $216,800 under posts, offset by a reduction of $180,900 under other staff costs, as well as reductions reflecting reduced requirements under experts and contractual services;

(ii)	Reduced requirements ($3,800) under contractual services for this subprogramme that supported the proposed increase under contractual services for programme support to strengthen the provision to cover the costs of data processing services, including workstation support and licences;
(d)	Programme support. Resource changes reflect an increase of $30,100, which comprises:
(i)	The higher standard price of the core software package for non-field personnel outside of United Nations Headquarters ($5,000);

(ii)	Additional resources ($25,100) to strengthen the provision for data processing services for workstation support covering the end user, and for central infrastructure hardware for UNODC regular budget activities.
Policymaking organs

16.153	The resources proposed under this component would provide for requirements relating to standing intergovernmental organs and expert bodies and intergovernmental processes, the servicing of which is the responsibility of UNODC. The provisions for experts serving on committees in their individual capacity are in accordance with General Assembly resolution 2491 (XXIII), as amended by resolutions 41/176, 42/25, section VI, and 43/217, section IX, while the provisions for members of the functional commissions are in accordance with Assembly resolutions 1798 (XVII), 2128 (XX) and 2245 (XXI). Table 16.26 provides information on the standing intergovernmental organs and related resource requirements under the regular budget.

Executive direction and management
16.155	The executive direction and management component comprises the Office of the Executive Director and the Independent Evaluation Section.

16.156	The Executive Director is responsible for coordinating and providing leadership for all United Nations drug control and crime prevention activities to ensure the coherence of actions within the programme and the coordination, complementarities and non-duplication of such activities across the United Nations system. In that capacity, the Executive Director participates in the work of the United Nations System Chief Executives Board for Coordination. The Executive Director acts on behalf of the Secretary-General in fulfilling the responsibility that devolves upon the Executive Director under the terms of international treaties and resolutions of United Nations organs relating to international drug control or crime prevention. The responsibilities are combined with those of the Director-General of the United Nations Office at Vienna. The Office of the Executive Director is integrated with that of the Director-General and is supported with resources from the regular budget under section 1, Overall policymaking, direction and coordination.

16.157	The core functions of the Office of the Executive Director are: (a) to assist the Executive Director in the overall executive direction and management of UNODC; (b) to facilitate inter-office cooperation in the implementation of workplans and administrative matters; (c) to ensure the timely implementation of decisions and the coordination of inputs from all organizational units to the activities of the Office; and (d) to support the Executive Director in the overall leadership and coordination of the activities of UNODC with extensive research and substantive information to advise on issues of policy, resources and results management.

16.158	The Office of the Executive Director also coordinates cross-cutting institutional issues, such as the systematic inclusion of gender equality aspects in all areas of UNODC work and reaching gender parity in staff. The Gender Team in the Office of the Executive Director coordinates the implementation of the United Nations Office at Vienna/UNODC Strategy and Action Plan for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women (2022–2026) to ensure delivery of United Nations commitments on gender equality and the empowerment of women, including Sustainable Development Goal 5, through activities, such as supporting field offices to contextualize gender commitments to their setting, ensuring that the institutional mechanisms on gender mainstreaming are efficient, raising awareness and providing capacity-building for personnel to further strengthen capacity on gender issues across the UNODC programme of work. The United Nations Office at Vienna and UNODC continue to recognize high-impact policies and programmes on gender issues through an annual Gender Award and have strengthened their efforts on male engagement to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment.

16.159	The Independent Evaluation Section provides evaluation-based knowledge for decision-making to the Executive Director and Member States on countering and preventing drugs, crime and terrorism. The Section delivers high-quality human rights-responsive, gender-sensitive and contextualized independent evaluations, syntheses of evaluations and other oversight results, and evaluation capacity development for internal and external stakeholders, as well as the innovative web-based evaluation and knowledge management application, Unite Evaluations, to foster accountability and learning. By working in conjunction with a diverse set of partners, including United Nations, regional and national entities as well as academia and research entities, the Section responds to strategic priorities in UNODC mandated areas of work and offers technical advice to Member States on conducting their own government-led evaluations. Furthermore, the Section leads efforts for delivering results through joint and system-wide work, thereby, for example, delivering strategic evaluation-based products on countering and preventing terrorism and Sustainable Development Goal 16.

16.160	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the United Nations Office at Vienna and UNODC are integrating environmental management practices into their operations.

16.161	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 16.28. The low travel compliance rate in 2024 (40 per cent) was largely due to the late nomination of travellers and late event planning, which resulted in the late booking of travel. Compliance rates continue to be monitored with the introduction of the new mission travel request application as well as awareness-raising sessions for staff.
